p.s: We are consuming a lot and for all our consume, we have one goal: Buy a piece as cheap as it gets.
In Germany the online-newspaper Spiegel online interviewed ana germanGerman, that wanted to know who the fashion pieces made and where the pieces come from, she says.
She was shocked, when first hearing about the amoung of industries in the city of Dhaka and linked to that the toxification of the river Buriganga.
The interview also leads to the question, which would be, how long employees have to work and under which conditions.

Müller-Hellmann, the interested German that has a lot of knowledge about the fashion industry, especially the fast fashion sector, says, that the workers have to work 10-12 hours on a daily basis and often on the same factory slepsleep all day.
She also knows, that the employees often do not have a free day in a week.
Müller-Hellmann also says, that a boycott is not the optimal thing to do, because it wouldn't solve the main problem.
Furthermore she expresses that you would influence the lives of the employees in a negative way, by doing that.
The fault is coming from the brands, that produce there.
Also the politicians have to act right and standardize new standards, so the working conditions get better in these countries.

Finally you can say that a boycott would not solve the situation and the politicanspoliticians and the governments have to move and make steps into the right direction so the benefit comes to employer and employee.
